issue.title: üêõ `Sequence[str]` does not raise on `str`

repository.name: pydantic
repository.description: Data validation using Python type hints

issue.body:
## Change Summary

`sequence_validator` in `_internal._validators` has been changed to match Pydantic v1 behavior.

It is now impossible to use strings (`str` or `bytes`) subclasses as values for `Sequence[str]` schema.

## Related issue number

fix #5595 

## Checklist

* [x] Unit tests for the changes exist
* [x] Tests pass on CI and coverage remains at 100%
* [x] Documentation reflects the changes where applicable
* [x] `changes/<pull request or issue id>-<github username>.md` file added describing change
  (see [changes/README.md](https://github.com/samuelcolvin/pydantic/blob/master/changes/README.md) for details)
* [x] My PR is ready to review, **please add a comment including the phrase "please review" to assign reviewers**


Selected Reviewer: @samuelcolvin

body: I don't know if the different behavior between v1 and v2 is intentional, but in Python any string is considered a `Sequence[str]`. The potential confusion is a known issue (see https://github.com/python/typing/issues/256)

It looks like it's not only differs from Pydantic v1 but also from `list[str]` in the same v2.

IMO, the decision is there and this is just an erroneous behavior.

> It looks like it's not only differs from Pydantic v1 but also from `list[str]` in the same v2.

Because `str` obviously doesn't match `list[str]`.

> IMO, the decision is there and this is just an erroneous behavior.

the _erroneous behavior_ is not from pydantic, but a general issue regarding Python typing. My assumption is that pydantic maintainers wanted `v2` to be in accordance with the behavior of `Sequence[str]` with `str`, but maybe `v2` could deviate from the intended typing behavior (model strictness may be related here)

Okay, I agree with @lig that `str` should not be allowed as input to `Sequence[str]`.

Arguments:
* v1 didn't allow `str` as a `Sequence[str]`
* if you do want to allow `str`, you can just annotate as `str | Sequence[str]` - much easier than specifically disallowing `str` via a validator
* (most importantly) In discussion with @tiangolo we think 90%+ of usage would not want `str` to be allowed as input.

> if you do want to allow str, you can just annotate as str | Sequence[str] - much easier than specifically disallowing str via a validator

For the record, this is [how pytype behaves](https://github.com/python/typing/issues/256#issuecomment-902369240) for this use case. Maybe the `str` as `Sequence[str]` not accepted behavior could be indicated in docs? (or it's not that common to face this issue, and we avoid adding too much in docs)

@Viicos documenting this behavior seems like a good idea to me.

Let me also share my view on the `str`/`Sequence[str]` topic.

I honestly believe that it is not `typing` and in general not the language responsibility to make `str` distinguishable from `Sequence[str]`. However, it is exactly why Pydantic exists and its job is to help developers dealing with this behavior. Here is why.

There are three distinct levels here:
- Language
- Library
- Application

IMO, `typing` is on the Language layer as type annotations cannot lie about language features. And when the language says that distinguishing between `str` and `Sequence[str]` is the developer's job it doesn't necessarily mean that it's an Application level's job. These common quality of life cases are exactly why there are libraries like `Pydantic` out there.

Thus, let's agree to leave this tedious job of making `if not isinstance(value, str)` check every time we write `Sequence[str]` to the Library level.

I would also say that in some cases, type checkers interpret things a bit differently in some edge cases (like the `pytype` example above). If I find some time I'll try and make a PR regarding docs, if not done by maintainers until then
